module.title: Weather
module.description: Aviation weather theory, sources, and effects on UAS operations

lessons.title: Weather Sources and Briefings
objectives: Know where to obtain aviation weather information
Understand the three types of weather briefings

sections.title: Weather Information Sources
sections.content:
## Where to Get Weather for Flight Planning

As a Part 107 pilot, you're responsible for checking weather before every flight.

| Source | What It Provides | Access |
|---|---|---|
| **1800WXBrief.com** | Full briefings, METARs, TAFs, NOTAMs, TFRs | Website (Leidos) |
| **AviationWeather.gov** | METARs, TAFs, radar, satellite, prog charts | Website (FAA/NWS) |
| **Flight Service** | Verbal briefings from a specialist | Call **1-800-WX-BRIEF** |
| **B4UFLY App** | Airspace restrictions, TFRs, basic weather | FAA mobile app |
| **LAANC Apps** | Weather + airspace authorization | Various providers |
| **weather.gov** | General weather forecasts, radar, alerts | NWS website |

sections.title: Types of Weather Briefings
sections.content:
## The Three Briefing Types

When you call Flight Service or use 1800WXBrief.com, you can request three types:

### Standard Briefing

Complete weather picture — METARs, TAFs, winds aloft, NOTAMs, TFRs, AIRMETs/SIGMETs. Use when you haven't received a previous briefing.

### Abbreviated Briefing

Update to a previous briefing, or when you only need specific information. Tell the briefer what you already know.

### Outlook Briefing

For planning flights **6+ hours in advance**. Gives a general picture of expected conditions.

## Exam Tip

The exam will ask where to obtain weather information. Classic answer: **Flight Service (1-800-WX-BRIEF)** or **aviationweather.gov**. Know both.

sections.title: ASOS and AWOS
sections.content:
## What They Are

Both are **automated weather stations** at airports that continuously measure weather conditions.

| Feature | ASOS | AWOS |
|---|---|---|
| **Full Name** | Automated Surface Observing System | Automated Weather Observing System |
| **Operated By** | NWS, FAA, DOD (federal) | State/local governments |
| **Report Frequency** | Hourly (with specials) | **Every 1 minute** |
| **Precipitation Type** | Yes — can distinguish rain, snow | Limited |
| **Lightning Detection** | Yes | No (except AWOS-3PT) |
| **Icing Detection** | Yes | No |

## AWOS Levels

| Level | Capabilities |
|---|---|
| **AWOS-A** | Altimeter setting only |
| **AWOS-AV** | Altimeter + visibility |
| **AWOS-1** | Altimeter, visibility, temp, dewpoint, wind |
| **AWOS-2** | AWOS-1 + precipitation |
| **AWOS-3** | AWOS-2 + cloud ceiling |

## How to Access

- **Radio frequency** — listed on sectional chart near airport symbol
- **Phone** — many have numbers in Chart Supplement
- **Online** — aviationweather.gov shows ASOS/AWOS as METARs

lessons.title: METAR Decoding
objectives: Decode all elements of a METAR report
Interpret wind, visibility, and sky condition
Understand temperature/dewpoint spread and fog risk

sections.title: METAR Format
sections.content:
## This Is the Most Tested Weather Topic

METARs are **real-time weather observations** from airports. They're issued hourly (with special reports when conditions change). You must be able to decode every element.

## METAR Format Order

```
[Type] [Station] [Date/Time] [Modifier] [Wind] [Visibility] [Weather] [Sky Condition] [Temp/Dewpoint] [Altimeter] [Remarks]
```

## Complete Example

**METAR KORD 121856Z 22015G25KT 6SM -RA BR BKN015 OVC025 18/16 A2978 RMK AO2**

| Element | Code | Meaning |
|---|---|---|
| Report type | **METAR** | Routine hourly observation |
| Station | **KORD** | Chicago O'Hare |
| Date/Time | **121856Z** | 12th day, 1856 UTC |
| Wind | **22015G25KT** | From 220° at 15 kt, gusting 25 kt |
| Visibility | **6SM** | 6 statute miles |
| Weather | **-RA BR** | Light rain and mist |
| Sky Condition | **BKN015 OVC025** | Broken at 1,500 ft, Overcast at 2,500 ft |
| Temp/Dewpoint | **18/16** | 18°C / 16°C (2° spread — fog likely) |
| Altimeter | **A2978** | 29.78 inches Hg |

sections.title: Wind and Visibility
sections.content:
## Wind — How to Read It

Format: **DDDSSKT** or **DDDSSGSKT**

| Code | Meaning |
|---|---|
| **DDD** | Direction wind is coming FROM (three digits, true north) |
| **SS** | Sustained speed in knots |
| **G** | Gust indicator (if gusts ≥ 10 kt above sustained) |
| **KT** | Knots |

**Examples:**

| METAR Wind | Translation |
|---|---|
| **27015KT** | From 270° (west) at 15 knots |
| **18010G20KT** | From 180° (south) at 10 kt, gusting to 20 kt |
| **VRB03KT** | Variable direction at 3 knots |
| **00000KT** | Calm wind |

> Wind direction is where wind comes FROM, not where it's going.

## Visibility

Reported in **statute miles (SM)**:

| Code | Meaning |
|---|---|
| **10SM** | 10 statute miles (excellent) |
| **P6SM** | Greater than 6 statute miles |
| **3SM** | 3 statute miles (Part 107 minimum) |
| **1/2SM** | 0.5 statute miles |
| **M1/4SM** | Less than 1/4 mile (M = less than) |

**Key Rule:** Part 107 requires minimum **3 statute miles** from the control station.

sections.title: Sky Condition and Ceiling
sections.content:
## Cloud Coverage

Clouds are reported in **oktas** (eighths of sky covered):

| Code | Coverage | Oktas | Creates a Ceiling? |
|---|---|---|---|
| **SKC/CLR** | Clear | 0/8 | No |
| **FEW** | Few | 1–2/8 | **No** |
| **SCT** | Scattered | 3–4/8 | **No** |
| **BKN** | Broken | 5–7/8 | **YES** |
| **OVC** | Overcast | 8/8 | **YES** |

**Height is in hundreds of feet AGL:**

| Code | Meaning |
|---|---|
| **FEW030** | Few clouds at 3,000 ft AGL |
| **BKN015** | Broken at 1,500 ft AGL — this IS the ceiling |
| **OVC008** | Overcast at 800 ft AGL — this IS the ceiling |

## The Ceiling Definition

The **ceiling** is the height of the lowest **BKN or OVC** layer. FEW and SCT do NOT create a ceiling.

**Example:** FEW010 SCT025 BKN040 OVC080
- FEW at 1,000 ft — not a ceiling
- SCT at 2,500 ft — not a ceiling
- **BKN at 4,000 ft — THIS is the ceiling**
- OVC at 8,000 ft — also a ceiling layer, but BKN below is "official"

bogeyman.message: Only BKN and OVC create ceilings! If you see FEW020 SCT040 and nothing else, there is NO ceiling. This is heavily tested.

sections.title: Temperature, Dewpoint, and Fog
sections.content:
## Temperature and Dewpoint

Format: **TT/DD** (degrees Celsius)

| Code | Meaning |
|---|---|
| **18/16** | Temp 18°C, Dewpoint 16°C (2° spread — fog very likely) |
| **25/10** | Temp 25°C, Dewpoint 10°C (15° spread — dry) |
| **M02/M08** | Temp -2°C, Dewpoint -8°C (M = minus) |

## The Fog Rule

When temperature and dewpoint are within **3°C or less**, expect fog or mist:

| Spread | Fog Risk |
|---|---|
| ≤ 2°C | **Very likely** — dense fog possible |
| 2–4°C | **Likely** — mist probable |
| 4–6°C | **Possible** |
| > 6°C | **Unlikely** |

## Altimeter Setting

Format: **A####** (inches of mercury)

| Code | Meaning | Implication |
|---|---|---|
| **A2992** | 29.92 in Hg | Standard pressure |
| **A3025** | 30.25 in Hg | High pressure (good weather) |
| **A2955** | 29.55 in Hg | Low pressure (poor weather) |

> **Memory Aid:** High altimeter = High pressure = Happy weather.

bogeyman.message: Temp/dewpoint spread ≤ 3°C = fog is likely or imminent. If a METAR shows 15/14, expect fog to form soon. This is tested heavily!

lessons.title: TAF Interpretation
objectives: Understand the difference between METAR and TAF
Decode TAF change indicators (FM, TEMPO, BECMG)

sections.title: TAF Format and Structure
sections.content:
## What TAFs Are

A TAF is a **forecast** of weather conditions at a specific airport, covering **24 to 30 hours**. While a METAR tells you what's happening now, a TAF tells you what's expected.

## TAF Format

```
TAF [Station] [Issue Date/Time] [Valid Period] [Forecast Groups]
```

## Example with Decode

**TAF KJFK 121720Z 1218/1318 18012KT 5SM HZ BKN020 FM122200 24018G30KT 2SM +TSRA OVC010**

| Element | Code | Meaning |
|---|---|---|
| Type | **TAF** | Terminal Aerodrome Forecast |
| Station | **KJFK** | JFK Airport, New York |
| Issued | **121720Z** | Issued 12th at 1720 UTC |
| Valid | **1218/1318** | Valid from 12th 1800Z to 13th 1800Z (24 hrs) |
| **Base forecast** | **18012KT 5SM HZ BKN020** | Wind 180° at 12 kt, 5SM haze, broken at 2,000 ft |
| **FM (From)** | **FM122200** | Starting at 2200Z on the 12th |
| New conditions | **24018G30KT 2SM +TSRA OVC010** | Wind 240° at 18 gusting 30, 2SM, heavy thunderstorms |

sections.title: Change Indicators
sections.content:
## FM, TEMPO, BECMG, PROB

| Indicator | Meaning | Duration |
|---|---|---|
| **FM** (From) | Complete change to new conditions | Starts new forecast period |
| **TEMPO** | Temporary fluctuation | Lasts **less than 1 hour** at a time |
| **BECMG** | Gradual transition | Change occurs over **1–2 hours** |
| **PROB30/PROB40** | 30% or 40% probability | Used only for precipitation/visibility |

## Understanding TEMPO

TEMPO 1223/1302 2SM +TSRA OVC008CB

- Between 2300Z on the 12th and 0200Z on the 13th
- Temporarily: 2SM visibility, heavy thunderstorms, overcast at 800 ft with cumulonimbus
- Each occurrence lasts **less than 1 hour**

## Understanding BECMG

BECMG 1306/1308 30010KT P6SM SCT040

- Between 0600Z and 0800Z on the 13th
- Conditions will gradually become: wind 300° at 10 kt, visibility >6SM, scattered at 4,000 ft

## Exam Tip

All TAF times are in **UTC (Zulu)**. The exam may ask you to convert to local time.

lessons.title: Density Altitude and Performance
objectives: Understand density altitude and its calculation
Know the effects of 'high, hot, and humid' conditions
Apply density altitude to flight planning

sections.title: Understanding Density Altitude
sections.content:
## What It Is

Density altitude is the **altitude at which the air "feels" based on its density**, regardless of your actual altitude. It's the single most important performance concept in aviation weather.

## The Formula

**Density Altitude = Pressure Altitude + [120 × (Outside Air Temp – Standard Temp)]**

Where:
- Standard temperature at sea level = 15°C
- Temperature decreases ~2°C per 1,000 feet

## The Three Enemies of Performance

**"High, Hot, and Humid"** = High density altitude = Degraded performance

| Factor | Why It Hurts |
|---|---|
| **High elevation** | Less air pressure = thinner air |
| **High temperature** | Warm air expands = thinner air |
| **High humidity** | Water vapor is lighter than dry air |

sections.title: Effects on Your Drone
sections.content:
## How High Density Altitude Affects Performance

In high density altitude conditions:

- **Reduced lift** — propellers generate less thrust
- **Reduced battery life** — motors must work harder
- **Reduced climb rate** — takes longer to reach altitude
- **Reduced maximum altitude** — may not reach 400 ft safely
- **Reduced payload capacity** — may need to fly lighter

## Real-World Example

Flying in Denver, CO (elevation 5,280 ft) on a hot August day (95°F / 35°C):

- Standard temp at 5,280 ft would be about 4.4°C
- Actual temp is 35°C — that's 30.6°C above standard
- Density altitude ≈ 5,280 + (120 × 30.6) = **~8,950 ft**

Your drone will perform as if it's flying at nearly **9,000 feet** even though you're on the ground in Denver.

## Standard Temperature Reference

| Altitude (ft) | Standard Temp |
|---|---|
| Sea level | 15°C / 59°F |
| 3,000 | 9°C / 48°F |
| 5,000 | 5°C / 41°F |
| 7,000 | 1°C / 34°F |
| 10,000 | -5°C / 23°F |

bogeyman.message: If the question describes 'a hot summer day at a high-elevation airport,' think density altitude. The answer will involve reduced performance.

sections.title: Wind Effects on Performance
sections.content:
## How Wind Affects Your sUAS

**Headwind (flying into the wind):**
- Reduces ground speed
- Increases battery consumption
- Reduces effective range

**Tailwind (wind behind you):**
- Increases ground speed going out
- BUT you fly into the wind coming back
- Can push you past planned range before you realize

**Crosswind:**
- Drone must "crab" (angle into wind)
- Reduces effective forward speed
- Can cause handling difficulties

## Mechanical Turbulence

When wind flows over obstacles, it creates **turbulence on the downwind (lee) side**.

**Avoid:**
- Flying on downwind side of buildings or ridges
- Flying in gaps between buildings (wind tunnel effect)
- Low altitude in gusty conditions near structures

## Wind Shear

Sudden change in wind speed or direction. Can cause:
- Sudden loss of altitude
- Loss of control
- Unexpected position changes

Most common near frontal boundaries, thunderstorms, and temperature inversions.

lessons.title: Hazardous Weather
objectives: Identify the four types of fog
Understand icing and its effects on drones

sections.title: Thunderstorms and Microbursts
sections.content:
## The Three Stages of a Thunderstorm

| Stage | Dominant Feature | Duration | Danger |
|---|---|---|---|
| **Cumulus** | Updrafts only | 5–10 min | Low |
| **Mature** | Updrafts AND downdrafts | 10–20 min | **HIGHEST** |
| **Dissipating** | Downdrafts only | 10–15 min | Decreasing |

## Three Requirements for Formation

1. **Moisture** — sufficient water vapor
2. **Lifting action** — front, terrain, or heating forces air up
3. **Instability** — atmosphere allows air to keep rising

## Microbursts — Extremely Dangerous

| Characteristic | Detail |
|---|---|
| Size | 0.5 to 4 km diameter |
| Duration | **5–15 minutes** |
| Wind speeds | Can exceed **150 mph** |
| Danger | Causes sudden wind shifts |

**Why they're lethal:** An aircraft encounters headwind (gains lift), then suddenly tailwind (loses lift) as it passes through.

## Safety Rule

**Stay at least 20 miles away from thunderstorms.** If you can hear thunder, the storm is within 5 NM — too close to fly.

bogeyman.message: The exam tests the three requirements for thunderstorms: Moisture, Lifting action, Instability. Also know the three stages and that mature is most dangerous.

sections.title: Types of Fog
sections.content:
## The Four Types You Need to Know

### Radiation Fog

- Forms on **clear, calm nights** when ground radiates heat
- Most common in valleys and low areas
- **Burns off within 1–2 hours after sunrise**
- Requires: clear skies, light wind, high humidity

### Advection Fog

- Warm, moist air moves over a **cold surface**
- Can form with wind (unlike radiation fog)
- **Does NOT burn off** with sunrise — can persist all day
- Common along coastlines (marine layer)

### Upslope Fog

- Moist air pushed **up a slope** by wind
- Persists as long as upslope wind continues
- Common on windward sides of mountains

### Steam Fog (Evaporation Fog)

- **Cold air** moves over **warm water**
- Water evaporates and immediately condenses
- Appears as "steam" rising from water
- Usually shallow (50–200 ft)

## Predicting Fog from METAR

Look at temperature/dewpoint spread:
- **18/16** (2° spread) → fog forming or imminent
- **22/08** (14° spread) → fog very unlikely

bogeyman.message: Radiation fog: clear night + calm wind + moist air. It dissipates after sunrise. Advection fog does NOT burn off — it can persist all day. Know the difference!

sections.title: Icing and Other Hazards
sections.content:
## How Icing Affects Your Drone

| Type | Effect |
|---|---|
| **Propeller icing** | Changes blade shape → reduced thrust, vibration |
| **Airframe icing** | Adds weight → reduced lift and endurance |
| **Sensor icing** | Camera, GPS, barometer covered → degraded data |
| **Battery effects** | Cold temps reduce capacity and output |

## When to Expect Icing

- Temperature between **0°C and -10°C** with visible moisture
- Most dangerous zone: **0°C to -5°C** (supercooled water)
- If METAR shows temps near freezing with precipitation, assess icing risk

## Lightning

**Direct threats to drones:**
- Direct strike — instantly destroys electronics
- EMI — disrupts GPS, control link, sensors even from nearby strikes
- Induced currents — damage from nearby lightning

**Safety Rules:**
- Don't fly if thunderstorms are within 10+ NM
- If you can **hear thunder**, storm is within 5 NM — too close
- If you can **see lightning**, storm is within 25 NM — reassess

## Fronts

| Front Type | Weather | Movement |
|---|---|---|
| **Cold** | Violent but brief — thunderstorms, wind shifts | Fast (25–40 mph) |
| **Warm** | Prolonged poor visibility, drizzle, fog | Slow (10–20 mph) |
| **Stationary** | Weather persists for days — clouds, drizzle | None |
| **Occluded** | Most complex — severe weather possible | Variable |
